abstract.p: American Ref-Fuel plant manager Steve Bossotti letter holds October 10 editorial on alternate energy sources failed to consider garbage

block.p: Your Oct. 10 editorial ''Powering Up'' usefully urged ''serious efforts to support clean, renewable energy, and government leadership to promote'' conservation. Absent from your position was consideration of the 1.1 million tons of garbage we are paying to haul off Long Island every year, each ton with the fuel value of a barrel of imported oil.

Your Oct. 10 editorial ''Powering Up'' usefully urged ''serious efforts to support clean, renewable energy, and government leadership to promote'' conservation. Absent from your position was consideration of the 1.1 million tons of garbage we are paying to haul off Long Island every year, each ton with the fuel value of a barrel of imported oil.

Despite this, some environmentalists still say garbage is not a renewable fuel. As a practical matter, the energy that could be recovered from the tons of garbage we're hauling away (and in the process consuming fuel and creating diesel pollution and traffic congestion) should be among the options under consideration.

Today, the waste-to-energy plant in Hempstead burns the trash produced by about a million people to generate enough electricity to power 65,000 homes, and is a good neighbor in the community. It's time we explore the double benefits of using garbage for fuel: producing energy and reducing pollution.
Steve Bossotti Plant Mgr., American Ref-Fuel Hempstead
